A VOICE FROM OUTSIDE.
Public sentiment in the University is apparently awakening from her strange, slumbrous indifference to the importance of some
training in elocution. By elocution is not
meant the bombastic oratory which, under the
old regime, acquired the name of "sophomoric" because it was wont to bear an especial profusion of leaf and flower, at that stage
of the college course. Very different is the
faculty of adequately giving expression to
thought, the training by which the mind may
bring forth out her treasures things new and
old for the benefit of the public.
If a man have anything to say, surely it is
important that he should know how to express
his ideas in good, intelligible English; surely
it is well that, by a clear voice, by correct intonation, by appropriate gestures, by every
legitimate means, he should be trained to
communicate his thought in the most forcible
and effective way possible. A lecturer may
speak on a subject of profound interest; he
may be the greatest living authority on that
subject ; yet little profit to have heard him, if
his language be involved, his utterance indistinct, and no connecting chord thrill with the
message from his mind to his audience.
The apathy which has hitherto enveloped
this important subject at last begins to break
away. The excellent article which appeared
in THE NEWS-LETTER last June, from a distinguished professor, advises the organization
of a senate, which may afford the much-needed practice in public speaking.
This is not the first evidence that the students of the Johns Hopkins University have
themselves felt the need of some opportunity
for training in the great art of giving vocal
expression to thought. Some years ago a
senate was successfully established, and several efforts have been made to start debating
societies. Those who were in the University
about three years ago may remember the
Taney Debating Society, which some
thoughtful students inaugurated, but which
soon, unhappily, perished of inanition.

The failure of this and similar efforts has
been due, not altogether to lack of interest
among the students, but to the absence of cooperation by the faculty. This is suggested in
the able article above referred to, and should
not be overlooked.
By judicious selection of leaders, wise
formation of plans and the kind and efficient
protection and guidance of the powers that be,
let us hope that before the class of '98 shall
have received all the "honors, rights and privileges" to the degree of A. B. appertaining
a senate may have been established on a firm
basis. This senate the Twentieth Century may
mature into a time-honored institution that
shall furnish to the world not only "full men,"
but "ready men ;" not only men who know
something, but men who have learned how to
express clearly and forcibly what they wish
others to know.
A Friend of the University.
PROFESSOR WARREN IN ROME.
Professor Minton Warren has resumed his
post as head of the Latin Department. He
was in Rome from October r, 1896, to July r,
1897, as Director of the American School of
Classical Studies. This institution, founded in
1895, corresponds in its scope to the American
School of Classical Studies at Athens. The instruction at the school might be called an advanced laboratory course for classical students.
Italy is the huge laboratory, the working desks
being chiefly at Rome and at Pompeii. Etruscan and Roman art and architecture, inscriptions on temples, on monuments and coins,
early Christian works of art hidden in catacombs—all these and many other things are
studied at their very birthplace. Last year
twelve students, all graduates, were in attendance. Two of them—Mr. Gordon Laing and
Mr. Charles Hoeing — were Johns Hopkins
men. Mr. Laing is now teaching Latin at
Bryn-Mawr College. Professor Marquand, of
Princeton, and several professors resident at
Rome, were associated in the work with Professor Warren.

and Princess Helena ; saw His Holiness, the
Pope, at the consistory, in which Satolli was

Professor Warren spent some time in studying
manuscripts at various Italian libraries. He
passed through Switzerland, Paris and London, and arrived at Boston on September 21.

JAMES ELLIS HUMPHREY.
FRANKLIN STORY CONANT.
On Sunday, October 3, at 3 P. M., a meeting to commemorate the deaths of Dr. Humphrey and Dr. Conant was held in Donovan
Room. A great part of the faculty, especially
the members from the Biological Department,
many friends of the deceased, and students,
were present. Three resolutions were passed:
"1. Copies of the following minutes are to
be sent to the trustees of Amherst College, to
the trustees of the Johns Hopkins University,
to the Johns Hopkins University Circular, and
to the family of Professor Humphrey.
"The faculty and students of the Johns
Hopkins University have assembled with other
friends to express their sorrow at the great loss
they have sustained in the untimely death of
their colleague, teacher and friend, James Ellis
Humphrey, who died at his post in the courageous discharge of duties of unusual and difficult nature, a leader in the fore ranks of the
army of natural sciences. They wish to make
an expression of the high esteem in which he
was held as worker and teacher, and of the
cherished memory of a genial and valued
friend.
"In the course of his three years' service at
this University Dr. Humphrey had succeeded
in steadily impressing his usefulness upon the
department with which he was connected until
he seemed to have become an almost essential
factor in its successful conduct. More and
more frequently both pupils and colleagues
learned to draw on his well-ordered store of
knowledge and to trust his judgment, which
they were ever proving to be sound and accurate. His endless patience and care as a
teacher gave assurance and encouragement to
his pupils, who sought his advice confident of
ready and willing response to their appeals. To
him nothing was a trouble which promised to
be helpful to members of his class. If pains-

taking be really akin to genius, he fell but little
short of that distinction. Perhaps no one ever
exemplified better than he the beauty of orderliness. Nothing with which he had to do was
out of place or lost, whether of things tangible
or facts in memory. Books, papers, instruments, and his good store of knowledge
seemed ever to be at places of greatest convenience for his command. The promptness
with which he would turn to a special pamphlet
case and produce at request some long lost
monograph would cause upon our faces a smile
of admiration—even though mixed with envy.
Still, it must be added, this exceeding orderliness was in no wise linked with a petty, narrow nature, which this quality often bespeaks.
For Humphrey was large and liberal in all his
thoughts and dealings. In matters doctrinal
he accepted that which was most evidently
true; in politics he had broken all hampering
ties, and aimed to be governed by the principles which promised the greatest good. His
industry had become a byword among his fellows. To be called as hard a worker as Humphrey was to enjoy enviable repute as a student. To overwork, indeed, and a consequent
lowered state of health, may probably be attributed the lamentable catastrophe of his
death. In spite of warnings, and against the
wishes of one whose pleasure and comfort were
always of supremest moment to him, he went,
because the duty of going seemed too plain to
resist.
"And then he fell—a loss to the University
which the memory of his character and example lightens but little ; a loss to his more intimate friends, which nothing but the hand of
unfeeling time will remove ; a bereavement to
those yet nearer to him, upon whom we must
not intrude.
"2. Copies of the following resolution are
to be sent to the University Circular, to the
faculty of Williams College and to the mother
of Dr. Conant:
"We, the friends and companions and instructors of Franklin Story Conant, having
assembled to express the sorrow with which we
have heard the sad news of his death, wish to
record our love and esteem for the generous,

THE SClENTlrIC DEPARTMENTS.
Several improvements were made in the
various scientific departments during the summer. The most noticeable is the establishment
of a new mechanical workshop in the basement of the physical laboratory. Various machine tools are at hand and a skilled machinist
is in charge. A lathe is soon to be installed.
It will no longer be necessary to send away to
have new apparatus made and old repaired,
but all such work will be done in this new
shop. The advanced students are to receive
instruction in instrument-making, etc., under
the skilled mechanic.
The storage-battery-room has been rearranged. More cells and a large new switchboard have been put in. The whole building
is being renovated.
The current from these cells is some times
used in the chemical laboratory, as well as to
run the various pieces of machinery put in
about a year ago in the department of Dr.
Morse.
A manual of laboratory practice, by Dr.
Ames, covering the work of the minor course,
is now going through the press.
The Naturalist's Field Club held a regular meeting on Tuesday, October 12, at 5
P. M., in the lecture-room of the biological
laboratory. Anybody interested in natural
history can become a member of this club by
applying to the secretary, Mr. Waters. There
are no dues.
The geological students took their first trip
of the season last Saturday. They visited the
region of sedimentary formations along the
Severn River, especially at Round Bay and
the bluffs opposite Annapolis.
Mr. E. Emmet Reid, fellow in chemistry,
was at work all summer in the basement of the
chemical laboratory making preparations to
be used in his thesis work of the present term.

THE NEWS-LETTER starts upon its second
year with the earnest hope that it may adequately fulfill its object the object, namely,
of recording the doings and the opinions of
the students, graduate and undergraduate, of
the University. This it proposes to do to the
best of its ability ; and with a considerably
larger staff of editors and more experience in
practical journalistic work, it may hope to
avoid some of the errors, and supply some of
the deficiencies apparent in the four numbers
issued last spring.
The success of the paper, however, is
mainly dependent upon the hearty co-operation of the students themselves. They must
read the paper and write for it ; and incidently subscribe to it, too. For the lucre thereby
obtained is a very useful grease—"filthy"
though it be—for lubricating the machinery of
publication.
It is also to be hoped that the Medical
School may be induced to take some interest
in T H E NEWS-LETTER. However hardworked they may be, the reason they generally adduce for their non-interest in University matters, they can and should at least keep
themselves informed, through THE NEWSLETTER, of the progress of events in their own
and the other departments of the University.

The past summer, which has been a season
of rest and recreation for most of our students,
and ingtructors has had a fatal ending for two
of them, whose scientific zeal kept them at
their work. Last June a party of students of
this University, under the direction of Professor Humphrey of the Biological Department, left for Jamaica to carry on their work
in the Marine Laboratory there. Shortly before the return of the expedition Professor
Humphrey was smitten by the fever and died
within a few days. Mr. Clark, a member of
the party, was also attacked, but recovered.
On the way home Franklin Story Conant fell
a victim to the same dread malady that had
stricken his two companions, and died a day
after reaching Boston.
Drs. Humphrey and Conant were both
men of marked ability in their line of work,
and were very popular with the men in their
departments.
Dr. Humphrey had just been appointed
professor of
, and Dr. Conant
had received the appointment to the Bruce fellowship for the coming year. Dr. Conant was
one of the originators of THE NEWS-LETTER,
which will sadly miss the aid of his ready pen.
He was a man of strong character, an earnest
worker in the Y. M. C. A. and in charitable
circles, and of ready helpfulness to all who
called upon him for assistance.
A new spirit in athletics has invaded the
University precincts, and there is enthusiasm
and practical effort to make unprecedented
progress. The most conducive factor to this
state of affairs, no doubt, is the cage and the
new gymnasium. The personal work of several men is another cause, and the attendance
at practice of the football candidates has been
unusually significant of the determination of
the men to hustle on the gridiron this fall for
the Black and Blue.
Much is to be expected from Johns Hopkins in athletics, for we are about to have unexcelled advantages for the development of

The new gymnasium and cage which
Messrs. J. J. Walsh & Son are building for the
University are now beginning to assume
shape, and the builders say that barring an unusual run of bad weather they will finish their
work by the middle of December. The walls
are already up as far as the first floor, and the
general outlines of the building begin to appear. The architects, Messrs. Baldwin & Pennington, seem to have used the space to the
best advantage, and have given us a gymnasium not large, but splendidly arranged, and a
cage the largest and best in the country.
The space, fronting 103 feet on Howard
street and running back 130 feet to Little Garden street, has been divided, giving a cage 130
x65 feet, and the gymnasium 130x35 feet.
The cage, from which the students expect so
much for Hopkins athletics, will have walls 25
feet high, will be covered by a trussed roof,
and lighted by electricity. The warm sunlight
will be let in by twelve windows, 14x4 feet—
six at each end—and by three skylights, each
10x40 feet. It is proposed to heat it by large
stoves placed in the corners. It will have a
dirt-clay floor, and around it a cinder runningtrack. Wire gratings will protect the windows,
and the walls will probably be padded to some
extent in the baseball season. The northern
wall, 25x128 feet, will have no windows, and
will make a number of good handball courts.
For lacrosse, baseball and football the cage is
excellent.
The remaining space, 35x130 feet, is occupied by the gymnasium proper, consisting of
a basement 12 feet high, running its entire
length a first story of the same length, and a
second story running 40 feet from Little Garden street. The basement will contain lavatory, engine, janitor's, bathing and lockerrooms. The bathroom will be 13 feet square
and will have two needle baths and six shower
baths. The locker-room, 35x90 feet and 12

feet high, will be an ideal room for this purpose. It will have a cement floor, be lighted
by eighteen windows 4x5 feet, and when
equipped with 300 lockers of the most improved pattern will be a treat to the students,
who, in this respect, have suffered badly heretofore.
Above the locker-room the gymnasium hall,
35x90 feet, with side walls 20 feet high, is an
improvement in many respects on t h e old
room. It will be better lighted, drier and better heated. Eighteen windows—fifteen on the
side and three on Howard street—each 4x10
feet, and two skylights, 8x2o feet, will make
this room very bright and attractive. The fifteen windows on the side look into the cage,
and when an exhibition or games are given in
the cage spectators can sit here and watch the
contests below them.
On the first floor a large room, 36x21 feet,
looks out on Little Garden street. This was,
on the suggestion of Dr. Crenshaw, set aside
as a room where students may spend some
leisure moments between recitations, may chat
together, fight over old battles again, smoke
and feel free from the restraints imposed upon
them in the lecture halls. It is hoped and believed that this room will bring students closer
together and create more enthusiasm in athletics.
Directly over this room are the Director's
office and a large room 24x34 feet, where any
athletic meetings may be held, and in which
trophies may be placed on exhibition. Five
windows look from this into the gymnasium
hall, and spectators can watch from this point
the classes exercising.
The outward appearance also, especially on
Howard street, will be imposing, and the
whole structure bids fair to be both useful and
ornamental.

PROF. FOSTER'S LECTURE.
Sir Michael Foster, professor of physiology
at Cambridge University, England, and the
author of a number of standard text books, delivered a lecture in McCoy Hall Monday afternoon, at the invitation of the medical faculty of
the University. There was a large audience
present. On the platform with Professor Foster were President Gilman, and Drs. Osler,
Welch and Howell, of the Medical School.
President Gilman introduced the lecturer with
a few well-chosen words.
Professor Foster began by a comparison of
Johns Hopkins with 'Cambridge. Johns Hopkins, he said, had its future before it, and by
reason of its youth could branch out on the
lines of the latest modern improvements in the
educational system. Cambridge, on the other
hand, with the glamor of antiquity, had many
of the evils of age. It was, indeed, so fast
bound by its traditions as to render innovations extremely difficult.
One of the greatest reforms lately carried
out at Cambridge was in the courses and examinations. The strict classical course formerly necessary for degree left the graduate
well equipped with knowledge which would
be of little use to him, but ignorant of many
sciences which might be of practical use. The
present system of electives was a great change
for the better.
The system of examinations has also undergone radical changes from the early ages.
The examination system has always been a
barrier to progress. "Improvements," it was
claimed, "might discourage the examination
system." Until at length it seemed a question
whether the University existed for examinations, or examinations existed for the University.
The latest advance, however, is a modern
rule which enables a student to enter Cambridge without taking a written examination,
provided he satisfies the proper persons of his
fitness to do his work after entering. After

entering he may pursue his studies and even
take a degree without examination. He must,
however, be shown to have contributed something to knowledge.
On Tuesday, October 13, President Gilman
lectured before the Historical Department
upon the new edition of De Tocqueville's
works.
De Tocqueville, a prominent French publicist of the earlier part of this century, was
sent to America by the French 'Government
to investigate the prison system. While in
America he was entertained by the prominent
men of the day and every opportunity afforded him to pursue his work. The result of this
visit was his standard work, "Democracy in
America."
President Gilman was invited to write the
introduction to the new edition, and accepted.
It is an interesting fact in this connection that
Dr. Gilman, after seeking for certain material
for his work in the Boston Public Library, unsuccessfully, finally found it in the Johns
Hopkins Library.
The Graduate Students' Association gave its
first reception of a series last Friday night in
Levering Hall. Mr. C. E. Waters, President
of the Association, made a short talk of welcome, and then introduced Professor Ira
Remsen, who spoke of one or two results of
his observation of student life at Johns Hopkins University since the University started.
He said in effect that at the start there was
difficulty in getting students far enough advanced to undertake the work that the faculty
desired them to do ; but now students come
too well prepared—for they had been all over
the work (so they say at least) which it is desired that they do here. He deplored the
shearing down of university work into the domain of the college.
Dr. Remsen also said that he had read recently an article by a German who had been
professor in an American university, in which
the writer characterized the American university students as "uncomfortably industrious."

A VOICE FROM OUTSIDE.
Public sentiment in the University is apparently awakening from her strange, slumbrous indifference to the importance of some
training in elocution. By elocution is not
meant the bombastic oratory which, under the
old regime, acquired the name of "sophomoric" because it was wont to bear an especial profusion of leaf and flower, at that stage
of the college course. Very different is the
faculty of adequately giving expression to
thought, the training by which the mind may
bring forth out her treasures things new and
old for the benefit of the public.
If a man have anything to say, surely it is
important that he should know how to express
his ideas in good, intelligible English; surely
it is well that, by a clear voice, by correct intonation, by appropriate gestures, by every
legitimate means, he should be trained to
communicate his thought in the most forcible
and effective way possible. A lecturer may
speak on a subject of profound interest; he
may be the greatest living authority on that
subject ; yet little profit to have heard him, if
his language be involved, his utterance indistinct, and no connecting chord thrill with the
message from his mind to his audience.
The apathy which has hitherto enveloped
this important subject at last begins to break
away. The excellent article which appeared
in THE NEWS-LETTER last June, from a distinguished professor, advises the organization
of a senate, which may afford the much-needed practice in public speaking.
This is not the first evidence that the students of the Johns Hopkins University have
themselves felt the need of some opportunity
for training in the great art of giving vocal
expression to thought. Some years ago a
senate was successfully established, and several efforts have been made to start debating
societies. Those who were in the University
about three years ago may remember the
Taney Debating Society, which some
thoughtful students inaugurated, but which
soon, unhappily, perished of inanition.

PROFESSOR WARREN IN ROME.
Professor Minton Warren has resumed his
post as head of the Latin Department. He
was in Rome from October r, 1896, to July r,
1897, as Director of the American School of
Classical Studies. This institution, founded in
1895, corresponds in its scope to the American
School of Classical Studies at Athens. The instruction at the school might be called an advanced laboratory course for classical students.
Italy is the huge laboratory, the working desks
being chiefly at Rome and at Pompeii. Etruscan and Roman art and architecture, inscriptions on temples, on monuments and coins,
early Christian works of art hidden in catacombs—all these and many other things are
studied at their very birthplace. Last year
twelve students, all graduates, were in attendance. Two of them—Mr. Gordon Laing and
Mr. Charles Hoeing — were Johns Hopkins
men. Mr. Laing is now teaching Latin at
Bryn-Mawr College. Professor Marquand, of
Princeton, and several professors resident at
Rome, were associated in the work with Professor Warren.

On Sunday, October 3, at 3 P. M., a meeting to commemorate the deaths of Dr. Humphrey and Dr. Conant was held in Donovan
Room. A great part of the faculty, especially
the members from the Biological Department,
many friends of the deceased, and students,
were present. Three resolutions were passed:
"1. Copies of the following minutes are to
be sent to the trustees of Amherst College, to
the trustees of the Johns Hopkins University,
to the Johns Hopkins University Circular, and
to the family of Professor Humphrey.
"The faculty and students of the Johns
Hopkins University have assembled with other
friends to express their sorrow at the great loss
they have sustained in the untimely death of
their colleague, teacher and friend, James Ellis
Humphrey, who died at his post in the courageous discharge of duties of unusual and difficult nature, a leader in the fore ranks of the
army of natural sciences. They wish to make
an expression of the high esteem in which he
was held as worker and teacher, and of the
cherished memory of a genial and valued
friend.
"In the course of his three years' service at
this University Dr. Humphrey had succeeded
in steadily impressing his usefulness upon the
department with which he was connected until
he seemed to have become an almost essential
factor in its successful conduct. More and
more frequently both pupils and colleagues
learned to draw on his well-ordered store of
knowledge and to trust his judgment, which
they were ever proving to be sound and accurate. His endless patience and care as a
teacher gave assurance and encouragement to
his pupils, who sought his advice confident of
ready and willing response to their appeals. To
him nothing was a trouble which promised to
be helpful to members of his class. If pains-

taking be really akin to genius, he fell but little
short of that distinction. Perhaps no one ever
exemplified better than he the beauty of orderliness. Nothing with which he had to do was
out of place or lost, whether of things tangible
or facts in memory. Books, papers, instruments, and his good store of knowledge
seemed ever to be at places of greatest convenience for his command. The promptness
with which he would turn to a special pamphlet
case and produce at request some long lost
monograph would cause upon our faces a smile
of admiration—even though mixed with envy.
Still, it must be added, this exceeding orderliness was in no wise linked with a petty, narrow nature, which this quality often bespeaks.
For Humphrey was large and liberal in all his
thoughts and dealings. In matters doctrinal
he accepted that which was most evidently
true; in politics he had broken all hampering
ties, and aimed to be governed by the principles which promised the greatest good. His
industry had become a byword among his fellows. To be called as hard a worker as Humphrey was to enjoy enviable repute as a student. To overwork, indeed, and a consequent
lowered state of health, may probably be attributed the lamentable catastrophe of his
death. In spite of warnings, and against the
wishes of one whose pleasure and comfort were
always of supremest moment to him, he went,
because the duty of going seemed too plain to
resist.
"And then he fell—a loss to the University
which the memory of his character and example lightens but little ; a loss to his more intimate friends, which nothing but the hand of
unfeeling time will remove ; a bereavement to
those yet nearer to him, upon whom we must
not intrude.

PROF. FOSTER'S LECTURE.
Sir Michael Foster, professor of physiology
at Cambridge University, England, and the
author of a number of standard text books, delivered a lecture in McCoy Hall Monday afternoon, at the invitation of the medical faculty of
the University. There was a large audience
present. On the platform with Professor Foster were President Gilman, and Drs. Osler,
Welch and Howell, of the Medical School.
President Gilman introduced the lecturer with
a few well-chosen words.
Professor Foster began by a comparison of
Johns Hopkins with 'Cambridge. Johns Hopkins, he said, had its future before it, and by
reason of its youth could branch out on the
lines of the latest modern improvements in the
educational system. Cambridge, on the other
hand, with the glamor of antiquity, had many
of the evils of age. It was, indeed, so fast
bound by its traditions as to render innovations extremely difficult.
One of the greatest reforms lately carried
out at Cambridge was in the courses and examinations. The strict classical course formerly necessary for degree left the graduate
well equipped with knowledge which would
be of little use to him, but ignorant of many
sciences which might be of practical use. The
present system of electives was a great change
for the better.
The system of examinations has also undergone radical changes from the early ages.
The examination system has always been a
barrier to progress. "Improvements," it was
claimed, "might discourage the examination
system." Until at length it seemed a question
whether the University existed for examinations, or examinations existed for the University.
The latest advance, however, is a modern
rule which enables a student to enter Cambridge without taking a written examination,
provided he satisfies the proper persons of his
fitness to do his work after entering. After

entering he may pursue his studies and even
take a degree without examination. He must,
however, be shown to have contributed something to knowledge.
On Tuesday, October 13, President Gilman
lectured before the Historical Department
upon the new edition of De Tocqueville's
works.
De Tocqueville, a prominent French publicist of the earlier part of this century, was
sent to America by the French 'Government
to investigate the prison system. While in
America he was entertained by the prominent
men of the day and every opportunity afforded him to pursue his work. The result of this
visit was his standard work, "Democracy in
America."
President Gilman was invited to write the
introduction to the new edition, and accepted.
It is an interesting fact in this connection that
Dr. Gilman, after seeking for certain material
for his work in the Boston Public Library, unsuccessfully, finally found it in the Johns
Hopkins Library.
The Graduate Students' Association gave its
first reception of a series last Friday night in
Levering Hall. Mr. C. E. Waters, President
of the Association, made a short talk of welcome, and then introduced Professor Ira
Remsen, who spoke of one or two results of
his observation of student life at Johns Hopkins University since the University started.
He said in effect that at the start there was
difficulty in getting students far enough advanced to undertake the work that the faculty
desired them to do ; but now students come
too well prepared—for they had been all over
the work (so they say at least) which it is desired that they do here. He deplored the
shearing down of university work into the domain of the college.
Dr. Remsen also said that he had read recently an article by a German who had been
professor in an American university, in which
the writer characterized the American university students as "uncomfortably industrious."

The annual reception which the University
Y. M. C. A. gives to new students was held
the evening of October 4 in Levering Hall.

the founder of Levering Hall, and offered
Hopkins athletes the use of the Y. M. C. A.
gymnasiums until the completion of their own
building. President Gilman made a characteristic speech, in which he suggested to new
students some of the opportunities for general
culture to be found in and about Baltimore.
Mr. Morris L. Barr, the new secretary, was
present, and made announcements in regard to
the year's work. Refreshments were served by
the reception committee.
Prof. Herbert B. Adams will lead a class in
the study of the life of Christ. The sessions
will be held in Professor Adams' room in McCoy Hall at9 o'clock every Saturday morning,

Morning prayers are now led regularly by
Dean Griffin in the chapel in Levering Hall
from 8:45 to 8:55 o'clock. Entrance is on
Eutaw street, the door leading from McCoy
Hall being closed until after the morning
service.
Perhaps the most pleasant and comfortable
room in all the University buildings is the
reading-room in Levering Hall. It is supplied
with more than seventy papers and periodicals,
and is open to all members of the University
from 8:15 A. M. to 6:30 P. M.
